definition: to set off firecrackers
to put/to place/to release/to free/to let go/to let out/to set off (fireworks)
to explode or burst/to quick fry or quick boil
bamboo/CL:棵[ke1],支[zhi1],根[gen1]/Kangxi radical 118

sentences.english: It is dangerous to shoot off fireworks.
The Spring Festival in the morning, open the door plug and firecrackers, called the "first opened the firecracker went off."
sentences.chinese: 春节早晨，开门大吉，先放爆竹，叫做“开门炮仗”。

sentences.english: At about 12 o'clock, some parents and children light crackers.
sentences.chinese: 大约到了12点，一些家长带着孩子就开始放爆竹了。

sentences.english: EXAMPLE: The old truck made a sudden backfire which sounded like a firecracker.
sentences.chinese: 旧卡车突然出现回火，声音像放爆竹一般。

sentences.english: I was so brave that I let off firecrackers by myself.
sentences.chinese: 我在北京过除夕，我很勇敢，自己放爆竹。

to see in the New Year/to stay up all night on lunar New Year's Eve
firecrackers set off at the stroke of midnight on New Year's Day (a Chinese tradition)
New Year's Day in the lunar calendar
last day of the lunar year/Chinese New Year's Eve
to offer sacrifices to the kitchen god
to burn paper offerings (as part of religious ceremony)
seeing off the kitchen god 灶神[Zao4 shen2] (traditional rite)
usher out the old, greet the new/esp. to see in the New Year
